json_cpp2 package

Submodules

json_cpp2.json_list module

class json_cpp2.json_list.JsonList(list_type: Optional[type] = None, iterable=None, allow_null_values: bool = True)

Bases: list, JsonParsable

Provides json translation for iterable types.

append(item) → None

Validates type and nullability and adds the element to the list

Raises:

  • TypeError – when item is of the wrong type

  • RuntimeError – when item is null and allow_null_values is set to False

Parameters:

item (any) – value to be added to the list

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

Example:

>>> l = JsonList(int, allow_null_values=False)
>>> l.append(1)
>>> l.append(2)
>>> l.append(3)
>>> print(l)
[1,2,3]
static create_class(name: Optional[str] = None, list_type: Optional[type] = None, iterable=None, allow_null_values: bool = True) → type

Creates a new type with a JsonList specification

Parameters:

  • name (str) – name of the class to be created. if empty, an autogenerated name will be provided

  • list_type (supported type) – supported type. if empty, the list will allow elements from any supported type

  • iterable (iterable) – initial values for every new instance of the class. if empty, the list will be initialized empty

  • allow_null_values (bool) – allows the list to hold null values. they will be translated to None. default is True

Returns:

the new type

Return type:

type

Example:

>>> IntList = JsonList.create_class(list_type=int, iterable=[1,2,3])
>>> l = IntList()
>>> l.append(4)
>>> l
[1, 2, 3, 4]
>>> l.append("a string")
Traceback (most recent call last):
 ...
TypeError: value of wrong type: expected <class 'int'>, received <class 'str'>
get(member_name: str) → JsonParsable

Copies a member from on every element of the list into a new list.

Parameters:

member_name (str) – the name of the member to be copied to the new list

Returns:

a JsonList with the results

Return type:

JsonList

Example:

>>> from json_cpp2 import JsonObject
>>> l = JsonList(JsonObject)
>>> l.append(JsonObject(x=10, y=15))
>>> l.append(JsonObject(x=20, y=25))
>>> l.append(JsonObject(x=30, y=35))
>>> l.get('x')
[10, 20, 30]
>>> l.get('y')
[15, 25, 35]
load(json_string: str) → JsonParsable

Parses a json_string and loads the values into the list, validating type and nullability

Parameters:

json_string – valid json string

Returns:

the list itself

Example:

>>> l = JsonList()
>>> l.load('[1,null,"hello",4,{"x":10,"y":20}]')
[1, None, 'hello', 4, {"x":10,"y":20}]
>>> print(l[4].x)
10
map(item_function)

Executes a function on every element of the list and saves the results into a new list.

Parameters:

item_function (callable) – the name of the member to be copied to the new list

Returns:

a JsonList with the results

Return type:

JsonList

Example:

>>> from json_cpp2 import JsonObject
>>> l = JsonList(JsonObject)
>>> l.append(JsonObject(x=10, y=15))
>>> l.append(JsonObject(x=20, y=25))
>>> l.append(JsonObject(x=30, y=35))
>>> l.map(lambda i: i.x + i.y)
[25, 45, 65]
>>> l.map(lambda i: i.x - 5)
[5, 15, 25]
>>> l.map(lambda i: int((i.x ** 2 + i.y ** 2) ** .5))
[18, 32, 46]
select(member_names) → JsonParsable

Creates a list of objects with new objects of a new type containing with a subset of members from the originals

Parameters:

member_names (list of str) – list of member to be included in the new list

Returns:

the new list of objects of the new type

Return type:

JsonList

Example:

>>> from json_cpp2 import JsonObject
>>> l = JsonList(JsonObject)
>>> l.append(JsonObject(x=10, y=15, z=5))
>>> l.append(JsonObject(x=20, y=25, z=5))
>>> l.append(JsonObject(x=30, y=35, z=5))
>>> l.select(["x","y"])
[{"x":10,"y":15}, {"x":20,"y":25}, {"x":30,"y":35}]
to_file(file_path: str) → None

Saves the list to a file in json format

Parameters:

file_path (str) – path to the file

Return type:

None

Example:

>>> l = JsonList(int)
>>> l.append(1)
>>> l.append(2)
>>> l.append(3)
>>> l.to_file("data.json")
>>> open('data.json','r').read()
'[1,2,3]'
where(lambda_criteria) → JsonParsable

Creates a list with elements that passes a criteria

Parameters:

lambda_criteria (lambda) – lambda receiving each element and returning a bool

Returns:

the new list

Return type:

JsonList

json_cpp2.json_object module

class json_cpp2.json_object.JsonObject(_mandatory_members: Optional[list] = None, _allow_undefined_members: bool = True, **kwargs)

Bases: JsonParsable

Provides json translation for objects.

static create_class(_name: Optional[str] = None, _mandatory_members: Optional[list] = None, _allow_undefined_members: bool = True, **kwargs) → type

Creates a new type with a JsonObject specification

Parameters:

  • _name – (optional) name of the class to be created. if empty, an autogenerated name will be provided

  • _mandatory_members – list of strings containing the names of the mandatory members

  • _allow_undefined_members – boolean. default True. allows additional members to be added during parsing

  • kwargs – list of members and values

Returns:

the new type

format(format_string: str) → str

Creates a formatted string using the values of the objects and a format specification

Parameters:

format_string (str (see https://www.w3schools.com/python/ref_string_format.asp)) – format specification

Returns:

the formatted string

Return type:

str

Example:

>>> c = JsonObject(x=10, y=20)
>>> c.format("'x' is equal to {x} and 'y' is equal to {y}")
"'x' is equal to 10 and 'y' is equal to 20"
>>> p = JsonObject(name="John", address=JsonObject(street="oak", number=1876))
>>> p.format("{name} lives in {address.number} {address.street}")
'John lives in 1876 oak'
>>> f = JsonObject(x = 10.0 / 3.0, pos=2)
>>> f.format("x={x:.2f} in position {pos:04d}")
'x=3.33 in position 0002'
keys() → list

List of member names defines in the object

Returns:

the list of member names

Return type:

JsonList(str)

Example:

>>> JsonObject(x=10,y=20).keys()
['x', 'y']
load(json_string: str) → JsonParsable

Parses a json_string and loads the members into the object, validating type

Parameters:

json_string – valid json string

Returns:

the object itself

Return type:

JsonObject

Example:

>>> c = JsonObject(x=int, y=int)
>>> c.load('{"x":10,"y":20}')
{"x":10,"y":20}
select(member_names: list)

creates a new JsonObject with a subset of members from the original object

Parameters:

member_names (list of str) – list of members names to be included in the new object

Returns:

the new JsonObject

Return type:

JsonObject

Example:

>>> c3 = JsonObject(x=10,y=20,z=30)
>>> c3.select(("x","y"))
{"x":10,"y":20}
to_file(file_path: str) → None

Saves the list to a file in json format

Parameters:

file_path (str) – path to the file

Return type:

None

Example:

>>> o = JsonObject(a=10, b=20)
>>> o.to_file('object_data.json')
>>> open('object_data.json', 'r').read()
'{"a":10,"b":20}'

json_cpp2.json_parser module

class json_cpp2.json_parser.JsonParser

Bases: object

Provides access to the json parsing and writing functionality.

static check_supported_type(value_or_type) → None

Raises an exception if value or type is not supported by json-cpp

Parameters:

value_or_type (any value or type) – value or type to be checked

Raises:

TypeError – when value or type is not supported

Return type:

None

Example:

>>> JsonParser.check_supported_type(None)
>>> JsonParser.check_supported_type(bool)
>>> JsonParser.check_supported_type(True)
>>> JsonParser.check_supported_type(False)
>>> JsonParser.check_supported_type(int)
>>> JsonParser.check_supported_type(5)
>>> JsonParser.check_supported_type(float)
>>> JsonParser.check_supported_type("a string")
>>> JsonParser.check_supported_type(object)
Traceback (most recent call last):
 ...
TypeError: type <class 'object'> is not supported
classmethod from_file(file_path: str)

Creates an instance of the corresponding type (None, bool, int, float, string, JsonObject or JsonList) and loads the values from a file containing a valid json string.

Parameters:

file_path (str) – path to the file

Returns:

the value in its corresponding type

Return type:

None, bool, int, float, string, JsonObject or JsonList

Example:

>>> open('data.json','w').write('{"a":10,"b":20}')
15
>>> o = JsonParser.from_file("data.json")
>>> print(o.a)
10
>>> print(o.b)
20
classmethod from_url(*args, **kwargs)

Creates an instance of the corresponding type (None, bool, int, float, string, JsonObject or JsonList) and loads the values from an url containing a valid json string.

Raises:

HTTPError – when failes to download content

Parameters:

args – passed through to request.get (see https://www.w3schools.com/python/ref_requests_get.asp)

Returns:

the value in its corresponding type

Return type:

None, bool, int, float, string, JsonObject or JsonList

Example:

>>> o = JsonParser.from_url("http://echo.jsontest.com/member1/value/member2/5")
>>> print(o.member1)
value
>>> print(o.member2)
5
>>> o = JsonParser.from_url("https://bad.url/test.json")
Traceback (most recent call last):
...
requests.exceptions.ConnectionError: HTTPSConnectionPool(host='bad.url', port=443): ...
static is_supported_type(value_or_type) → bool

Checks if a value or type is supported by json-cpp

Parameters:

value_or_type (any value or type) – value or type to be checked

Returns:

True if value or type is supported, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

Example:

>>> JsonParser.is_supported_type(None)
True
>>> JsonParser.is_supported_type(bool)
True
>>> JsonParser.is_supported_type(True)
True
>>> JsonParser.is_supported_type(False)
True
>>> JsonParser.is_supported_type(int)
True
>>> JsonParser.is_supported_type(5)
True
>>> JsonParser.is_supported_type(float)
True
>>> JsonParser.is_supported_type(object)
False
static parse(json_string: str)

Parses a valid json string into the corresponding value type (None, bool, int, float, string, JsonObject or JsonList)

Raises:

RuntimeError – when string cannot be parsed

Parameters:

json_string (str) – the string to be parsed

Returns:

the value in its corresponding type

Return type:

None, bool, int, float, string, JsonObject or JsonList

Example:

>>> JsonParser.parse('true')
True
>>> JsonParser.parse('[1,2,3]')
[1, 2, 3]
>>> JsonParser.parse('{"a":10,"b":20}').a == 10
True
>>> JsonParser.parse('{"a":10,"b":20}')['a'] == 10
True
static to_file(value, file_path: str) → None

Saves the value to a file in json format

Raises:

TypeError – if type of value is not supported

Parameters:

  • value (any supported value type) – value to be saved

  • file_path (str) – path to the file

Return type:

None

Example:

>>> JsonParser.to_file({'a':10, 'b':20}, 'data.json')
>>> open('data.json','r').read()
'{"a":10,"b":20}'
static to_json(value) → str

Converts any supported value to a valid json string

Parameters:

value (any supported type) – value or type to be converted

Returns:

Return type:

str

Raises:

TypeError – when value or type is not supported

Example:

>>> JsonParser.to_json(None)
'null'
>>> JsonParser.to_json(True)
'true'
>>> JsonParser.to_json([1,2,3,None])
'[1,2,3,null]'
>>> JsonParser.to_json((1,2,3,None))
'[1,2,3,null]'
>>> from json_cpp2 import JsonObject
>>> JsonParser.to_json(JsonObject(a=10,b=20))
'{"a":10,"b":20}'
>>> JsonParser.to_json({'a':10,'b':20})
'{"a":10,"b":20}'
